Work

Gumroad.com

2014 - Present

At Gumroad we were building a company that helped creators earn a living doing what they love.

Over the last year we’ve shipped a ton of stuff. This is taste of what I’ve worked on there.

  • Reading
  • Analytics
  • Mobile Apps
  • Marketing
  • Physical Goods
  • Other

Gumroad Reading

Overview

The web reading experience was one of the first projects I took on at Gumroad. It was the beginning of a shift in focus at Gumroad where previously we were focused on building the best selling experience for creators, now we also wanted to build a really great consumption experience for their audience. We had already done it with film, now it was time to do it with reading. Our goal was to build an experience for the web that was just as powerful as the experience in a native app like Kindle or iBooks. It’s mobile-friendly too.

Process

As the design lead on this project we took this feature from concept to rollout in just under a month. I started with competitive research, collective everything I could find on Kindle, iBooks, and others that were in the same space. From there I started sketching concepts, with these I usually sketch what my best case would be. From there we had a good idea of what we wanted to build and which features we wanted to include, now it was time to design som hi-fi comps. After iterating two or three times we were in a good place to jump into the browser. From there I started stubbing out the html, css and js so everything was in a good place for the engineers. After that it was in their hands, aside from some light polish here and there.

The Feature

Gumroad Analytics

Overview

Consumption analytics on Gumroad was one of the most powerful features we launched for creators while I was there. It gave creators a new insight into how their products were performing on a product and file level, whereas previously you were just making assumptions based off of the sales data. Now you can see which files in your best selling product are most popular and drill down even deeper to see the drop off rate for that song, video or book. It’s something no one else is really doing for all three verticals (music, video, and publishing).

Process

As the design lead I started by researching how other content focused sites were handled analytics for their creators. Each had their own unique way of doing it but the big difference between us and them was they were focused on one vertical like film or music. We need to make a tool the worked across film, music, and publishing. With that in mind and research done I started sketching concepts. Once those were in a good spot I start on hi-fi comps and posting for feedback. After a couple rounds iterating on the design I was ready to get into the browser and start writing the CSS/HTML and a some JS. From there I paired with an engineer to get the backend wrapped up. Like most of the other features we worked on this was shipped atomic. Meaning we had the grand vision then we broke that up into smaller more manageable shipments. This result is fewer bugs, less code to PR each time, and shipping faster.

The Feature
